entry.title: A Short Guide: Construct wave equationğŸš€
entry.content:
Wave equation

Construct wave equation

Vertical displacement function: $u(x,t)$

Mass density function: $\rho_{0}(x)$

Tension function: $T(x,t)$

Angle function: $\theta(x,t)$

Perfectly elastic string

Perfectly elastic string has the tension $T(x,t)$ is a constant $T_{0}$.

Perfectly flexible string

The force exert on every segment of perfectly flexible string is tangential, such tangential force is call tension.

Letâ€™s try to derive the one-dimensional wave equation with the functions above.

$$\text{slope of the segment} = \dfrac{\partial u}{\partial x} = \tan \theta(x, t) = \dfrac{\sin \theta(x, t)}{\cos \theta(x, t)} \approx \sin \theta(x, t) \approx \theta(x, t).$$

entry.title: Paper Note; (Review) Quantum computing with atomic qubits and Rydberg interactions Progress and challenges
entry.content:
Introduction

  • Paper: Quantum computing with atomic qubits and Rydberg interactions: Progress and challenges
  • Authors: M. Saffman
  • Subjects: Quantum Physics (quant-ph); Atomic Physics (physics.atom-ph)
  • Comment:

reviews

  • Reviews: 1,9,12,27

overall

  • Physical platforms of quantum computing: 2,3,4,5,6
    • Trapped ions: 2,3,4
    • Superconducting qubits: 5, 6
  • High fidelity quantum logic operations: 2,3,4,5,6,7,8
    • Close to thresholds for error correcting quantum: 2,3,4,5,6
    • Exceed thresholds for error correcting quantum: 7,8

neutral atom quantum computation architectures

  • Current architectures: Section 2;
    • Main fields:
      • Quantum simulation: 14,15,16
      • Quantum computation: 18,19,12,20,21, 22,23,24,25,26,27
    • Make qubit Part 1: Entanglement
      • Atomphoton-atom coupling: 28
      • Collision: 29,30,31
      • Rydberg interaction: 27,32,33,34,35,10,11,36,37,38,39,40,41
        • Rydberg interaction between individual atoms: 36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 41
    • Make qubit Part 2: Quantum encoding:
      • Standard method:
      • Ensemble encoding: 42,43,44,90,91
      • Collective encoding: 45,46
    • Make qubit Part 3: Debate on identical or heterogeneous qubits:
      • Identical qubits: 47
      • Heterogeneous qubits: 48

Fidelity

  • Fidelity: 10,11

DiVincenzo criteria - make large and scalable system

  • With out fidelity, other properties are dicussed in order of DiVincenzo criteria
  • Make large and scalable system: Section 2.1;
    • Make qubit Part 4: Netural atom basing:
      • Optical trap: 49,50,55,60,61,57,58,59,10
      • Magnetic trap: 51,52,53,54,56
    • Make qubit Part 5: Number of qubits: 62,63,13,64,60,65
    • Make qubit Part 6: Qubit atoms loading: 67,68,69,59,57,70,71,72,73
    • Make qubit Part 7: Optical qubit control: 57,74,79
    • Coherent single site addressing:
      • electro-optic modulators: 75
      • acousto-optic modulators: 76,77,59
      • piezo mirrors: 22
      • micro-electro-mechanical devices: 55,60
      • spatial light modulators: 78
        • digital mirror device (DMD) spatial light modulators: 59,10

DiVincenzo criteria - trap lifetime and coherence times

  • With out fidelity, other properties are dicussed in order of DiVincenzo criteria
  • Trap lifetime: Section 2.2;
    • Trap lifetime measured:
      • Cryogenic environment: 80
      • Error correction:
        • Array assembly experiments: 72,73
    • Trap lifetime is limited:
      • Heating: 81
    • Trap lifetime increasement:
      • Reduce heating:
        • Cryogenic environment:
        • Periodically recool trapped atoms: 82
      • Small code sizes:
      • fast measurements:
      • Rydberg has a long lifetimes:
      • Error correction:
        • Single atom transport: 84,85,86,87,88
        • Assembling: 72 (1D),73 (2D)
        • Single atom qubit: 42,46,89,90,43,44,91,92
  • Achievements for neutral atom coherence times: Section 3;
    • State transition (Dephasing): 93
    • Extending coherence times: 96,97,98,99,100,101,102,103
    • Application:
      • Atomic clocks and coherence times: 94,95
    • Rydberg magic trapping: Section 3.1;
      • Design Rydberg magic trapping (early): 104,18,12,105
        • Major experiment: 18
      • Design Rydberg magic trapping (matching wavelength):
        • Improvement: 106,107
        • Theoretical: 108
        • Ponderomotive potential measuring: 109
        • In 1D-array: 110
      • â€œLandscape modulatedâ€ trap: 111
      • Other implementations of the magic trapping:
        • AI: 112
        • Divalent atoms: 113,114
        • Magic magnetic trapping: 115

DiVincenzo criteria - qubit initialization and measurement

  • With out fidelity, other properties are dicussed in order of DiVincenzo criteria
  • Qubit initialization and measurement: Section 4;

DiVincenzo criteria - neutral atom logic gates

  • With out fidelity, other properties are dicussed in order of DiVincenzo criteria
  • Neutral atom logic gates: Section 5;
    • 1-qubit: Section 5.1;
    • 2-qubit: Section 5.2;
    • Fundamental limits to gate fidelity: Section 5.3;
    • Protocols for multi-qubit: Section 5.4;
    • High fidelity gates: Section 5.5;

Fig: Architecture for a neutral atom quantum computer

  • Platform: optical or magnetic traps
  • Atom array source: loading from reservoir of laser cooled atoms
    • and a fiducial logical state encoded in hyperfine-Zeeman ground substates is prepared with optical pumping
  • Logic gates: optical and microwave fields
  • Result measurements: measured with resonance fluorescence
  • Experiment atom: the heavy alkalis $\mathrm{Rb}$ and $\mathrm{Cs}$
    • Reasons:
      • easy to be optically or magnetically trapped
      • have well resolved excited state hyperfine splittings
  • DiVincenzo criteria

Fig: Encoding a $K$ qubit quantum register with neutral atoms

  • Figure A: standard method with one two-level atom per qubit
  • Figure B: ensemble encoding with $N$ two-level atoms per qubit
  • Figure C: collective encoding with $K$ qubits in one ensemble using atoms with $K+1$ internal levels

Fig: Fluorescence images of atoms in a 100 site 2D optical trap array

  • Figure left: 2D optical trap array
  • Figure right: 2D magnetic trap array

Fig: Contours labeled with \(\tau_{\mathrm{vac}}\) in seconds from $\tau_{\mathrm{vac}}>\frac{N_{\mathrm{code}} t_{\mathrm{qec}}}{\epsilon}$

Notes and Future visions

It is tempting to focus on gate fidelity as the most important challenge facing neutral atom quantum computation.

Optical traps for neutral atoms cannot be arbitrarily deep.

To minimize heating and decoherence rates the traps should be designed to satisfy a ground-Rydberg magic condition.

Q&A

  • Which institutions are doing the trapped ions and which are doing the superconducting qubits? ^86f797
    • trapped ions:
    • superconducting qubits:
  • What is the DiVincenzo criteria fitting including?
    1. a scalable physical system with well characterized qubits
    2. initialization of simple fiducial states
    3. long relevant decoherence times, much longer than the gate operation
    4. an universal set of quantum gates
    5. a qubit-specific measurement capability
  • Why we are interesting in coherence times of netural atoms?
    • phase difference produces coherence, make wave phase predictable
    • quantum decoherence means reduce the decoherence between quantum system and outside envirment, resulting in classic probability mix
    • by increasing the coherence times, we reduce the rate of coherence, make measurement possible
  • In neutral atom quantum computer, how does it work?
    • array of single atom qubits in optical or magnetic traps
    • logic gates are performed with some combination of optical and microwave fields
    • array is initialized from a reservoir of laser cooled atoms
    • results are measured with resonance fluorescence
    • atom used are heavy alkalis $\mathrm{Rb}$ and $\mathrm{Cs}$
  • How many ways are there used to make entanglements?
    • atomphoton-atom coupling
    • collision
    • Rydberg interaction
  • What are the intrinsic features of neutral atoms that make them well suited for multi-qubit experiments?
    • neutral atoms are all identical so that the qubit frequency $\omega_{q}$ is the same
  • What are the natural, synthetic, identical, heterogeneous qubits?
  • What methods are used to improve qubit loading from laser cooled atoms?
  • What is the best trap depth (energy well)?
    • optical traps for neutral atoms cannot be arbitrarily deep
    • optical traps: Cs, $\lambda=1.06 \mu \mathrm{m}$, intensity $20 \mathrm{mK}$
    • magnetic traps: $6 \mathrm{~T}$, intensity $4 \mathrm{mK}$
  • Why the trap lifetime is limited?
    • heating
    • collisional loss
  • How to incease the trap lifetime?
    • reduce heating:
      • cryogenic environment
      • periodically recool trapped atoms
    • small code sizes
    • fast measurements
    • Rydberg has a long lifetimes
    • error correction
  • What is the probability of having 1 bit lost in ERROR CORRECTION?
    • $\boxed{P_{\text {loss }}=N_{\text {code }}\left(1-e^{-t / \tau_{\text {vac }}}\right) \simeq N_{\text {code }} t / \tau_{\text {vac }}}$
      • $N_{\text {code }}$: # of qubits of quantum error correcting code
      • $\tau_{\mathrm{vac}}$: vacuum limited lifetime of each qubit
      • $P_{\text {loss }}$: probability of having lost at least one bit after time $t$
    • in multiple qubits, have $\boxed{\mathcal{O}(1 / N)}$ as efficiency of loss
  • If error being correctable, how much time we need for this correction?
    • $\boxed{\tau_{\mathrm{vac}}>\frac{N_{\mathrm{code}} t_{\mathrm{qec}}}{\epsilon}}$
      • $t_{\mathrm{qec}}$: duration we require for experiments, $t_{\mathrm{qec}}=0.1 N_{\mathrm{code}}$
  • If error being correctable, how much time we need for reloading?
    • $t_{\mathrm{qec}} \geq 1 / r_{\text {load }} \Longrightarrow \boxed{r_{\text {load }}>\frac{N_{\text {phys }}}{\tau_{\text {vac }} \epsilon}}$ [[#Fig Contours labeled with tau_ mathrm vac in seconds from tau_ mathrm vac frac N_ mathrm code t_ mathrm qec epsilon]]
      • $N_{\text {phys}}=$ number of qubit processor $\times$ $N_{\text {code}}$
      • $r_{\text {load }}$: time required to reload a lost atom
  • What is the expected temperature for cryogenic environment?
  • Comparison of coherence!
    • longitudinal relaxation $\left(T_{1}\right)$
      • sensitive to: external fields > light scattering
        • magnetic fields: for qubits encoded in Zeeman substates, cause transitions between states [[#^45762f]]
          • (transitions caused by low frequency magnetic fields are negligible)
        • microwave frequency fields: transitions
          • use RF shield
      • state transition: magnetic fields and microwave frequency fields
    • transverse relaxation $\left(T_{2}\right)$
      • sensitive to: dephasing mechanisms that preserve population but randomly change the relative phase of the qubit states
      • state transition: magnetic noise, intensity noise in optical traps (Dephasing)
  • What is the Zeeman substates? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeeman_effect
    • Zeeman effect: the splitting of a spectral line into several components in the presence of an electric field
    • Zeeman sub-levels is a function of magnetic field strength
  • What are the Rydberg magic traps and Rydberg magic condition?
    • Rydberg magic traps is an optimization on avoiding heating and collison
  • What is the ponderomotive potential? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ponderomotive_force
    • the ponderomotive force is a nonlinear force that a charged particle experiences in an inhomogeneous oscillating electromagnetic field
    • over a complete cycle this makes the particle move towards the area of lesser force
  • How does the ground-Rydberg magic traps has been developed over time?
    • problem of early magic trap: required relatively small detuning, causing:
      • excessive scattering rates
      • suboptimal coherence properties
    • solving: matching of the trapping potential to the Rydberg electron wavefunction
      • Rydberg electron wavefunction: $\alpha_{\mathrm{Ryd}}=-e^{2} /\left(m \omega ^{2}\right)$
      • bounded condition $\left|\alpha_{\mathrm{Ryd}}\right|<\left|\alpha_{\text {ground }}\right|$ and $\alpha_{\text {Ryd }}, \alpha_ {\text {ground }}<0$
  • How to briefly explain the â€œlandscape modulatedâ€ trap? Why the 3D overlap of the wavefunction with the repulsive ponderomotive potential leading to it?

entry.title: A Short Review: The topological materials and the topological order
entry.content:
From Hall Effect to topological materials

The entire field can be traced back to the earliest when the Hall effect was discovered. In 1879, Edwin Hall, a Ph.D. student at Johns Hopkins University in Maryland, discovered the Hall effect (QE). [1] This phenomenon indicates that a voltage proportional to the magnetic field will be generated in the direction perpendicular to the current and the applied magnetic field.

With the advancement of technology, the German physicist von Klitzing at Max Planck Institute discovered that when the magnetic field increases to a certain extent, the Hall voltage actually rises in steps. This is called the Integer Quantum Hall Effect (IQHE). [2] The integers appearing in the Hall effect are some topological quantum numbers, called Chern numbers. After observing a non-integer Hall voltage. The Fractional Quantum Hall Effect (FQHE) was discovered by Robert Laughlin, Daniel Tsui and others. [3][4]

In 2005, a new study guided the Quantum Spin Hall Effect (QSHE), which is essentially the quantization of the abnormal Hall effect part. [5] It brings us a new state of matter. We call them two-dimensional topological insulators (TI), and they have special edge effects: there are some special quantum states on the surface.

If one material is topologically nontrivial and another material is topologically trivial, put them together. There will be a topological phase change on the contact surface, and this phase change will have some physical phenomena: for example, the surface conductivity of topological insulators. In order to describe this phase transition, we need to find the topological invariants, such as Chern number [6] and Z2 invariant [7], or hopf fibration [8], topological order [9] and returning Thouless pump [8]. Based on Pontrjaginâ€™s research on the dual-band Hamiltonian in the three-momentum dimension, Dr. Alexandradinataâ€™s team studied a new topological invariant: returning Thouless pump (RTP), and did a detailed study of the Hopf-RTP relation. Generally speaking, different topological quantum states can be described by different topological invariants. Therefore, determining the topological invariant of the electronic structure of a material system is the core of judging its topological properties. [10][11] This topological invariant is closely related to Berryâ€™s phase [12][13], so Chernâ€“Gaussâ€“Bonnet theorem can be a very helpful tool. [14] Dr. Alexandradinata and Dr. Syzranov of UCSC both have important contribution in this field. [15] [8] [16] Some other information that I would like to check during phd are [17][18][19]. Dr. Alexandradinata most recent reseearch[8]

Quantum Spin Liquid and topological order

â€œQuantum Spin Liquidâ€ (QSL) was proposed by Anderson in a 1973 paper. In the original â€œResonating Valence Bondâ€ theory (RVB), there are some errors, so it has not received the attention it deserves. [20] After a long time, due to the discovery of high-temperature superconductivity, people renewed emphasis on quantum spin liquid, and Resonating Valence Bond and Valence Bond State (VBS) were gradually improved. [21] Spin liquid refers to spin frustration caused by a certain geometric symmetry or the complexity of interaction, a state in which a ground state presents a disordered state, including spin glass and quantum spin liquid. The biggest difference between quantum spin liquid and the former is the existence of long-range RVB. This quantum fluctuation means the existence of long-range entanglement, which is of great help to our understanding of entanglement. [24] QSL state has nothing to do with spontaneous symmetry breaking [22], so it does not involve Landau phase transition theory [23]. Our understanding of it may require a deeper understanding of topological order. This makes QSL research has great potential. The existence of long-range entanglement and strong coherence makes this field possible to lead topological quantum computing and quantum communication to make more progress in the future. This review is of great help to me in understanding the recent developments in the field of QSL research. [24] Dr. Syzranovâ€™s paper is also helpful here. [25]

In the previous section we mentioned the idea of topological order. In 1989, Wen Xiaogang put the fractional quantum Hall state on different topological manifolds to probe the new paradigm implicit in the fractional quantum Hall state. This brings us to the concept of topological order. [26][9] Different from Landauâ€™s symmetry breaking theory, topological order is a new state of matter. I donâ€™t know enough about it. I will carefully drill the basic theory in the phd stage to prepare for research. Citing the original paper here. [27]

Reference

[1] Hall, E. H. (1879). On a new action of the magnet on electric currents. American Journal of Mathematics, 2(3), 287-292.[2] Klitzing, K. V., Dorda, G., & Pepper, M. (1980). New method for high-accuracy determination of the fine-structure constant based on quantized Hall resistance. Physical review letters, 45(6), 494.
[3] Laughlin, R. B. (1983). Anomalous quantum Hall effect: an incompressible quantum fluid with fractionally charged excitations. Physical Review Letters, 50(18), 1395.
[4] Tsui, D. C., Stormer, H. L., & Gossard, A. C. (1982). Two-dimensional magnetotransport in the extreme quantum limit.
Physical Review Letters, 48(22), 1559.
[5] Kane, C. L., & Mele, E. J. (2005). Z 2 topological order and the quantum spin Hall effect. Physical review letters, 95(14), 146802.
[6] Chern, S. S. (1946). Characteristic classes of Hermitian manifolds. Annals of Mathematics, 85-121.
[7] Kane, C. L. (2013). Topological Band Theory and the â„¤2 Invariant. In Contemporary Concepts of Condensed Matter Science (Vol. 6, pp. 3-34). Elsevier.
[8] Nelson, A., Neupert, T., Alexandradinata, A., & BzduÅ¡ek, T. (2021). Delicate topology protected by rotation symmetry: Crystalline Hopf insulators and beyond. arXiv preprint arXiv:2111.09365.
[9] Wen, X. G., Wilczek, F., & Zee, A. (1989). Chiral spin states and superconductivity. Physical Review B, 39(16), 11413.[10] Sachdev, S. (1999). Quantum phase transitions. Physics world, 12(4), 33.
[11] Zeng, B., Chen, X., Zhou, D. L., & Wen, X. G. (2019). Quantum information meets quantum matter: From quantum entanglement to topological phases of many-body systems. Springer.
[12] Berry, M. V. (1984). Quantal phase factors accompanying adiabatic changes. Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. A. Mathematical and Physical Sciences, 392(1802), 45-57.
[13] Pancharatnam, S. (1956, December). Generalized theory of interference and its applications. In Proceedings of the Indian Academy of Sciences-Section A (Vol. 44, No. 6, pp. 398-417). Springer India.
[14] Chern, S. S. (1945). On the curvatura integra in a Riemannian manifold. Annals of Mathematics, 674-684.
[15] Alexandradinata, A., Fang, C., Gilbert, M. J., & Bernevig, B. A. (2014). Spin-orbit-free topological insulators without time-reversal symmetry. Physical review letters, 113(11), 116403.
[16] Syzranov, S. V., & Radzihovsky, L. (2018). High-dimensional disorder-driven phenomena in Weyl semimetals, semiconductors, and related systems. Annual Review of Condensed Matter Physics, 9, 35-58.
[17] Qi, X. L., & Zhang, S. C. (2011). Topological insulators and superconductors. Reviews of Modern Physics, 83(4), 1057.[18] Hasan, M. Z., & Kane, C. L. (2010). Topological insulators. Rev. Mod. Phys, 82(4), 3045-3067.
[19] KÃ¶nig, M., Buhmann, H., W. Molenkamp, L., Hughes, T., Liu, C. X., Qi, X. L., & Zhang, S. C. (2008). The quantum spin Hall effect: theory and experiment. Journal of the Physical Society of Japan, 77(3), 031007.
[20] Anderson, P. W. (1973). Resonating valence bonds: A new kind of insulator?. Materials Research Bulletin, 8(2), 153-160.[21] Anderson, P. W. (1987). The resonating valence bond state in La2CuO4 and superconductivity. science, 235(4793), 1196-1198.
[22] Miransky, V. A. (1994). Dynamical symmetry breaking in quantum field theories. World Scientific.
[23] Landau, L. (1936). The theory of phase transitions. Nature, 138(3498), 840-841.
[24] Savary, L., & Balents, L. (2016). Quantum spin liquids: a review. Reports on Progress in Physics, 80(1), 016502.
[25] Syzranov, S. V., & Ramirez, A. P. (2021). Hidden energy scale in geometrically frustrated systems: are quantum spin liquids achievable?. arXiv preprint arXiv:2105.08070.
[26] Wen, X. G. (2002). Quantum orders and symmetric spin liquids. Physical Review B, 65(16), 165113.
[27] Wen, X. G. Topological orders and Edge Escitations in FQH State. arXiv preprint cond-mat/9506066.
[28] Watanabe, H., Po, H. C., Zaletel, M. P., & Vishwanath, A. (2017). Closing the Gap in Band Theory. JCCM, 01.
[29] Braithwaite, V. (2017). Closing the gap between regulation and the community. Regulatory theory: foundations and applications, 25-42.
